The patient is a 51-year-old male with Down syndrome, chronic Hepatitis B, and a history of frequent urinary tract infections (UTIs) since undergoing posterior cervical laminectomy with Foley catheter placement earlier this month. He presents with Gram-negative bacterial septic shock, and his blood cultures have grown pan-sensitive Proteus mirabilis in the urinary catheter, as well as pan-sensitive Gram-negative rods in the blood cultures.

The patient is currently being treated with piperacillin/tazobactam, vancomycin, and cefepime. The plan is to continue the antibiotic treatment for a 14-day course. The goal is to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55-60, considering the patient's baseline systolic blood pressure (SBP) usually runs in the 90s. Adequate urine output (UOP) is being maintained at this blood pressure, and the Levophed infusion has been turned off. The femoral line will be discontinued once the patient is off pressors.

The patient is experiencing GU pain but has adequate UOP and no evidence of obstruction. Lidocaine jelly has been applied at the meatus, and oxycodone will be given as needed. If there is no relief, phenazopyridine may be tried.

The patient is also showing signs of acute renal failure, with pre-renal physiology versus acute tubular necrosis (ATN). The creatinine level has normalized at 0.9. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) will be performed when the patient is off pressors to evaluate for structural heart disease.

The patient has chronic Hepatitis B, and the usual doses of adefovir and lamivudine have been restarted. Preoperative medical clearance has been obtained for possible upcoming surgeries.

The patient is tolerating a regular diet with adequate oral intake and is repleted in potassium. Intravenous fluids are being given at keep-open (KVO), and a normal saline bolus may be given if the patient becomes hypotensive following discontinuation of Levophed.

The patient has a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line and will have the femoral line discontinued once off pressors. Midline placement for intravenous antibiotic therapy will be evaluated.

The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR)/do not intubate (DNI), confirmed with the sister who is also the healthcare proxy. The patient will remain in the ICU as long as pressor requirements remain, followed by transfer to the floor.
